ARTICLE.TITLE: East community joins ’Shoebox for a farmer’s wife’ initiative
ARTICLE.TEXT:
The “Shoebox for a farmer’s wife” initiative has touched residents of the east of Pretoria and they have gone out of their way to pack special Christmas boxes to give away.

Led by Ward 82 councillor Siobhan Muller, community members prepared boxes full of goodies for the wives of farmers in drought-stricken areas.

The initiative is the brainchild of the Women’s League in Wellington, which aims to let the farmers’ wives know that, while they are supporting their husbands, there are other people thinking of them.

Muller said when she heard about the project she encouraged members of the community to give as much as they could.

“We had a prerequisite of items that needed to be in the box such as a letter and a scarf, but people could add anything extra from perfume to chocolate,” she said.

The Menlyn Animal Clinic was used as a drop-off point and Muller said the offices were packed with boxes after only a week.

She said the response was overwhelming.

“It shows that people really care.”

The boxes will be transported to the north of Pretoria where they will ship along with hundreds of others to various drought-stricken areas.

“Our farmers and their workers are the people that give us our food and we would like to show appreciation. We need them.”

Security company Fidelity ADT sponsored two of their bakkies and another ward councillor gave his 4X4 vehicle to transport the boxes.

“All the bakkies were filled to the brim,” Muller said

Other ward councillors also joined in the initiative in different parts of the city.

“It shows that as South Africans we can pull together.”

Meanwhile, the lack of rain still remains a problem in many parts of the country, causing dry conditions and low reservoir levels.

According to water and sanitation minister Lindiwe Sisulu, enough rain to alleviate the situation was only expected in December.

“Farmers need all the support they can get,” said Muller.
